document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Dziriblatta Chopard, 1936 (Blattodea, Ectobiidae, Ectobiinae) from North Africa, Spain, and the Macaronesian islands. I. The nine subgenera of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Dziriblatta Chopard, 1936 (Blattodea, Ectobiidae, Ectobiinae) from North Africa, Spain, and the Macaronesian islands. I. The nine subgenera of the genus

Morocco . Syntypes : 1♂ , 1♀ , Mogador , Mz. Escalera (abd. of ♂ on slide: Bo 7, ♀ completely on slide: Bo 347) [Ma 2]

Description. Size.
Length of pronotum in male 1.79–1.92 (mean 1.84) mm, in female 2.18–2.50 (mean 2.30) mm.
Male structures. See under characters of the subgenus.

Colouration. Male.
Mainly dark brown, with pale yellowish lightenings. Head: dark with a light interocular stripe. Thorax ( Fig. 3N ): Nota with a ground pattern consisting of variously sized small brownish spots thinning out towards the transparent margins. The pattern is overlayed by dark colour in the central areas of the nota. The dark areas on meso- and metanotum may be variously lightened by longitudinal stripes revealing the dot pattern. Tegmina transparent, with some dark spots. Colour of legs varying between almost completely dark—with lightenings only at the coxa-trochanter joints and the tarsi—and completely yellowish. Abdomen ( Figs. 3 A–H): T2–5 anteriorly of the transversal ridge dark, posteriorly with dispersed dark spots near the transversal ridge fused to seven larger patches; T6,7 similar to preceding tergites, but median part dark up to the posterior border; T8–10 almost completely dark. Sternites dark with lightly coloured lateral margins. Female . Lighter coloured than male. Head as in male, but with lighter brown. Thorax ( Figs. 3O , 4 K–N): Nota with a similar ground pattern as in male, seldom overlayed by larger brownish markings. Tegmina as in male. Legs yellowish, at most darkened at the basal parts. Abdomen: Tergites similar as T 2–5 in male, but dark dots smaller and dark patches less intense; sternites very variable in colouration: seldom almost completely dark with light lateral margins, mostly with more extended lightenings, light areas with dispersed dark spots.

Distribution. In the southwestern corner of Morocco (SW of Marrakech) including the western part of the High Atlas, the Sous, and parts of the Anti-Atlas, at altitudes between 200 and 2400 m (Figs. 28, 30).

Remarks. The species
Dz. vicina Chopard, 1936b
, was described after a single female from the High Atlas, according to Chopard differing from
Dz. merrakescha
by the different colouration of the pronotum: in the latter only covered with small darker spots, while the former should additionally have a larger dark marking along the anterior margin of the disk ( Chopard 1943 , fig. 28).

The differences in the colouration of the females between
Dz. merrakescha
and
Dz. vicina
as indicated by Chopard are minimal; at other localities much darker specimens had been found ( Fig. 4L ). Moreover, most of the females collected at the type locality of
Dz. vivina
were considerably lighter coloured than the type specimen ( Figs. 4M, N ). Comparison of the male tergal glands from various localities does not allow a distinction of separate species. The differences in the structure of the glandular pit between the type specimen of
Dz. merrakescha
( Fig. 4G ) and males from the type locality of
Dz. vicina
( Fig. 4F ) are rather small and well encompassed by the range of variability found at a single locality (Ma 138, near the type locality of
Dz. merrakescha
, Figs. 4 A–E).
Dz. vicina
, therefore, has to be considered as a junior synonym of
Dz. merrakescha
.
